div.head: Hoff's Malt HOMAX
div.p: Ideal Food Beverage for Convalescents
and all who highly tax their strength in a hot climate, through strenuous work or sporting life.
Practically non-alcoholic
Homax is a delicious tonic.
Homax creates appetite.
Homax digests food.
Homax invigorates the nervous.
SOLE MANUFACTURER-
M. HOFF, Hamburg, Germany.
THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,

div.head: WHEN WHEAT FAILS.
div.p: Professor Silvanus Thompson writes « parti. cularly imtereeting article in the “World's Work” under the title “When Wheat Pails.” The rise in the price of wheat gives an added point to his cbesrvations, The qhap of to to chat something must be done to alter the conditions of wheat-growing if a shortage is to be avoided, and that the problem is even now being solved by the utilisation of electricity to fix the nitrogen in the air.

It is only in temperate countries that wheat will grow, and the wheat-growing area of the world is not mach more than 240,000,000 acres. Allowing twelve and a half bushels an acre, this means an annual crop of 3,000,000 bushels. As each wheat-eater consumes an average of four and half bushels per annum (this including 0-6 bushels for seed), the whest-growing area can furnish wheat fornot more than 666,000,000 souls. Already the .wheateaters number 585,000,000, and they are increasing, of course, alarmingly every year ; so that it will easily be seen that rae no time to lose in solving the problem of a sofficient wheat-supply. Even in 1911 it is caloulated that the world’s wheat- eaters will number 608,700,000, and by 1921 they will be well allotted 666,000,000. Since 1900 bread-eaters increased more than twice as fast as the area of Wheat cul- tivation.

In the United States the average wheat: yield per acre is 12 bashels ; in Argentina, 13 ; in India, Russia. South Australia, and Algeria, only 9; in Canada, 154 ; in Germany, 23; and in Norway, 25; while in New Zealand it rises to 25 1/2. Now the fertiliser required by wheat is nitrogen, either in the form of nitrates or nitrates, however are fast becoming exhausted; or are insufficient. Of sulphate of ammonia, made in gas-works, there is not nearly enough; guano is almost exhausted; and as for the Chilian salpetre (nitrate of soda), which has become "the great staple fertiliser of to-day," vast as are its reserves, they cannot possibly meet the demands made upon them. At the present rate of working, the Chilian nitrate mines will be exhausted in a period estimated by some at forty-eight years, by others at only sixteen.

There remains, then, the air as a source of nitrogen; and the problem has been how to force into chemical combination the nitrogen and oxygen in it: —“For a hundred years it has been known that any mere electric ae will cause a minute amount of the nitrogen of the air to enter into chemical combination with the oxygen. But the knowledge of how to effect this on a sufficient scale, and to generate nitrates commercially, is a recent achievement of science.”

Four-fifths of the air, of course, consist of nitrogens bat “free,” or uncombined, and theretore absolutely worthless as a fertiliser. Moreover, fixing the free gas has been found very difficult. Nine years ago Sir William Crookes said that if electric energy could be obtained at one seventeenth of a penny per unit, nitrate of soda might be wanafactured at £5 per ton, Chiliin saltpetre being then £7 10s aton. It is now £11 a ton. He added, however, that thoagh atiospheric nitrogen could be fixed, this bad only been done ou a very small scale. That, however, as stated, was nine years ago. Now three plants are actaally at work, ou @ commercial soale, fixing atmos- pherce nitrogen—one in Scotland, one in Berlin one at Notodden in Norway, with the processes used in which the latter part of the article deals. Nitrate of lime is here made, and on a scale which may be inferred from the fact that the new power-house which it was soon found necessary to erect can afford twenty six thousand h p. Other projects are being deve- loped for the manufacture of nitrates on a large scale, the power being always water- power, and the cost of electricity remarkably low, much less than Sir William ‘Crookes’ suggested one seventeenth of a penny. The nitrate of line produced is found quite equal as a fertiliser to Chilian saltpetre, and delivered, at Hamburg or Christiania, it is not much more than half as expensive. "Here, then,” the writer concludes, “is a great new industry established to meet the ever-nearing crisis in the agricultural world,”

div.head: St. Andrew's Church, Cairo.
div.p: The service to-morrow at 10.30 a.m. will be conducted by Mr. Float, of Alexandria.

div.head: Ministry of Finance.
div.p: Habib Bey Debbana, of the Finance Ministry, has retired on pension on the grounds of ill-health.

div.head: Ptomaine Poisoning.
div.p: Several cases of ptomaine poisoning, suspected of being due to bad meat, have occurred at Dia Birket-Saba.

div.head: Protection of Children
div.p: Hussein Pasha Roushdi has been appointed president of the Cairo Moslem Society for the Protection of Children.

div.head: Ministry of Education.
div.p: Ahmed Husni Effendi, of the Accounts Department, has been appointed Director of the Industrial Department of the Ministry of Education.

div.head: Blasting Fatality.
div.p: A man named Moussa Msah was engaged in blasting rock at Kerm Gamalie yesterday afternoon, when a flying stone struck him on the head, killing him instantaneously.

div.head: Assault Case.
div.p: The trial of Mansour Tabbakh on the charge of assaulting Dr. Saleh Soubhri at San Stefano Casino will take place at Alexandria Criminal Court on the 14th prox.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: A death occurred from plague at Alexandria yesterday afternoon. One case was discharged cured at Port Said, and one new case notified, thus leaving only five cases under treatment at present.

div.head: Accident to an Engine Driver.
div.p: The driver of the midday Cairo-Alexandria express, whilst leaning out of his engine, was struck by a wooden plank projecting from a goods train which was in motion. The man happily escaped with a broken arm.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: "Le Due Dame" is billed for this evening at the Alhambra Theatre. To-morrow afternoon "Guerra in tempo di pace" will be staged, and in the vening the Gemma Caimmi company will present "Le Maltre de Forges."

div.head: Foxhounds for Cairo.
div.p: The Papayanni S.S. "Alexandria," which arrived yesterday from Liverpool disembarked eighteen English foxhounds for Major Neil Haig, of the Inniskilling Dragoons, Cairo. The hounds were sent to Cairo last night.

div.head: Quarrel Between Italians.
div.p: Two Italians of Haret Fahda, Alexandria, quarrelled violently yesterday, and became so heated that knives were drawn. One of the men was mortally wounded in the chest and died in hospital almost immediately after having been transported there.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1and October 17 1,045,312 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 570,059 tons were Welsh 124,299 Newcastle, 163,848 Yorkshire, 86,492 Scotch and 100,614 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the coal imports totalled 1,039,057.

div.head: The Mahroussa.
div.p: The trip to sea recently made by the Khedivial yacht "Mahroussa" was not with the object of testing her engines which have never required the slightest repairs, but in order to test her speed after the cleaning of her hull, which had become coated with barnacles during her stay in Turkish waters.

div.head: Ports and Lights.
div.p: We understand that an exhaustive report on the Ports and Lighthouses Administration has been drawn up by the Court of Enquiry appointed to investigate the cases of corruption and bribery committed by several officials and employes of the Administration Advice is given, it is said, in this report as to the reforms which it will be necessary to carry out, and we understand the Chitty Bey will be charged by the Finance Ministry with the complete organisation of the Administration.

div.head: RUSSIA'S IMPORTS OF COTTON.
div.p: Mr. R. J. Barrett, editor of the "Financier," who is contributing a series of articles on Russian prospects, quotes some interesting statistics of cotton imports into that country.

The total amount in roubles of raw cotton imported into Russia in 1905 was nearly 67 millions, in 1906 71 millions. Of these totals the United States in 1905 supplied 25 1/2 millions, and in 1906 27 1/2 millions; Egypt, 8 3/4 millions and 12 millions for the two respective periods. The banace was divided between Great Britain, the East Indies and Brazil. For the first four months of the present year the total of raw cotton imported amounted to 29 1/4 million roubles, an increase of 2 millions as compared with the same period of 1906. Of this amount the United States sent 14 3/4 millions for the former period, or an increase of 2 millions over the latter. Egypt's figures are 4 1/2 and 6 1/4 millions respectively, the balance being divided among Great Britain, the East Indies and Brazil.

div.head: THE Hotel Casino San Stefano
div.p: Will be open during Winter
REDUCED PRICES

div.head: SECRET HISTORY OF EGYPT.
SIR E. MALET AND MR. BLUNT.
MR. BLUNT'S DISCOMFITURE.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday.
Sir E. Malet completely answers Mr. Blunt's last letter to the "Times."

In to-day's leading article the "Times" says that Mr. Blunt is hoist with own petard. His signal of discomfiture in this encounter serves as evidence to show that might be his fate at the hands of others whom he calls to the Bar of his lofty judgement.

Mr. Blunt belongs to that misguided class who seem to find their principal satisfaction in traducing their own countrymen, and who are ready to accept and use against them any evidence they can collect from the most unworthy witnesses.

div.head: DUKE OF DEVONSHIRE.
TO VISIT EGYPT.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday.
The Duke of Devonshire leaves for Egypt next week to recruit his health.

div.head: MINISTERS AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: It has been stated in some local newspapers that the Government intended to put a stop to the enstom of transferring the Ministers and the high offialals t9 Alecandtia’ Garing Oi hot season. Alexand¥a has been virtually the capital of Egypt during the summer months and the change from the terrible heat of Cairo is very weléume to a large number of high officials, and is said to be much appreciated as a sort of transition before they go on their usual long annual holiday to Europe. There does not, however, appear to be any foundation for the rumour and it is improbable that any change will be made. On the other hand there will be a tendency to keep more going in the official world of Cairo during the sommer months, as it is. generally recognised that the officialdom of the Capital has been suffered to relapse into a far too complete state of somnolence during the summer.

div.head: CAIRO AUTOMOBILE CLUB.
OPENING UP OF ROADS.
div.p: The Automobile Clab of Cairo is doing ca- pital work in the way of opening ap the roads to outlying districts to motor traffic, and motorists will be pleased to learn that the one obstacle which has hitherto existed on the road to Bedrasheen will in all probability be removed this winter, when a bridge is to-be built at the point where the road crosses the railway. The clab has had this matter in hand for some time, but it was difficult to seoure the services of a contractor who would do the work for a figure that was within the resources of the club to meet. The matter is now placed in the hands of M. Dreux, and permission having been obtained from the Railway Ad- ministration to build the bridge, it is hoped that the work will commence in a very short time. The road to Suez is also receiving the attention of the club, and this too should be in good condition for running shortly, while the old road to Hawendier is under repairs at the present time. The question of a road to Helouan is too hig an undertaking to be tackled by the club during the present year, but it is hoped that the growing needs of this suburb will justify the building of a road for vehicular traffic in the eyes of the Govern ment in the near future.

div.head: THE ABBAS THEATRE.
div.p: A crowded house at the Abbas Theatre accorded a great reception to the World's Royal Illusionists Company, who appeared in Cairo for the first time. It requires ah eacep- tionally good company to keep up interest for three hours in an entertainment which varies so little in its subject as, but for occasional interludes, the performance consisted of a succession of conjuring tricks, which, however, were so varied and so remarkably performed that the interest displayed was as keen at the fall of the curtain as it had been at the com- mencement, and tosay this is to accord the highest praise to the performers which it is possible to give. One can draw no distinctions as to the merit of the performers, they were all equally good, and no sooner had one convinced. the house that better could be done, when the next would put its convictions to light with a new mystery more marvellous than before, We have, as maybe seen, nothing but praise to give the performers, but of the management, who towards the latter part of thé evening allowed crowda}to collect at the sides of the theatre, and to stand, entirely exclading the yiew of the stage from those who were unfor- tunate enough to be seated in the end seats of the stalls, we have a very different opinion.

div.head: THE DENISHWAI PRISONERS.
PETITION FOR RELEASE.
SIR EDWARD GREY'S REPLY.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Saturday.

Sir Edward Grey replying to a petition from the Hon. S. Coleridge and others for the release of the Denishwai prisoners stated that the subject was recently discussed in Parliament and that he could not at present add to the statements he then made.

div.head: EGYPT'S FINANCIAL CRISIS.
div.p: In last months number of the "Revue des Deux Mondes" Pierre Arminjon deals with the financial crisis in Egypt. There is no such thing as an Egyptian industrial crisis, he says, for the simple reason that there are np great industries in Egypt. The evil from which the exchanges of Alexandria and Cairo are suffering at this moment is purely a financial crisis, similar to that which occurred in Argentina and Australia some fifteen years ago. To organise the exchanges and correct abuses a good law is needed, and the Government has already elaborated one. It permits the opening of exchanges authorised by the Government, and confides the direction of them to an assembly of commissaires, The present crisis ought to be a salutary lesson, but the writer hopes it will not destroy the spirit of speculation which is so essential to economic progress. Egypt cannot do without a more direct and active interest in the enter- prises in which they have placed the money of their clients. The great French banks should also do something to regulate the uses to which the capital is put at Cairo and Alexandria, and the financiers of London and Paris would do well to take more part in the administration of the Egyptian societies which they have helped to found. Many excesses might thus have been avoided and many losses spared.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF THE "VECTIS."
div.p: The P. and 0. steam cruising yacht “Vectis,” Captain A. Thompsop, arrived at Alexandria this morning with 71 passengers aboard, all of whom have left for Oairo. The “Veotis” will remain here until Thursday, when she will sail for Marseilles via Syracuse and Naples. Pas- sages for the voyage may be booked at the agent's offices, Messrs. Haselden and Co., Rue Averoff.

Among those who disembarked from the. “Vectis” this morning we noticed, Prince and Princess di Raffo C. Scarletta,, Lord and Grantly, the Hon. Edmands Lt Col? Kleynhens, Lt. Col. Jeffreys and Miss M. Jeffreys, Mejor BE Grant Burls, €.8.1., Col. and Mrs. E. T. Rodney Wilde, Col James Patchett, Capt. McQueen, Miss May’ Le Breton, Miss Beachoroft, Mr. and Mrs. R. C. Campbell, Mrs. Gaston Dru, Mr. H. D. Poster, Mr. and Mrs. J.H. Moore Garrett, Mr. and Mrs. J. Harrison.

div.head: BRITAIN'S INFLUENCE.
div.p: To The Editor of The "Egyptian Gazette"

Dear Sir,- While travelling among the Per- sian Gulf Arabs 1 met a party who weloomed me very warmly because | was an Englishman. They had a few copies of the ““Moayad” news- paper, and the chief told me that he had read them with the greatest interest, and added “truly you English are teaching true freedom to the whole Arabic world. Here is a paper printed in Cairo during the English occupation and the authorities allow it to be published in spite of the fact, that it criticises them very freely Here the Turks would not allow a paper to be published even if it praised the authorities for they would say it contained hidden sarcasms. Do you think the English will ever come here and give us the pleasure of writing and saying what we like?” I said that in twenty years they would be abusing the English as the Egyptians were. He added “Yes we are all children of Adam. He thought he could improve on Paradise.”
Yours, Truly
Traveller.
Alexandria, 16/10/07.

div.head: L'AGENCE REUTER
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur
de l' "Egyptian Gazette"

Je trouve dans les dépéches Reuter, a la ru- brique “Bank Retorns”, que la proportion de la réserve s’éléve cette semaine a 49 3/8 %, contre 46 1/2 % la semaine passée, Pourtant, le total des “Returns” est de 3.183.000 £. in- férieur & celui de vendredi dernier. Peut-étre votre chroniqueur financier pourra-t-il expli- quer cette apparente anomalie ou demander a l'agence des éclaircissements?
Agreez, etc.
Un abonne,
Alexandrie, le 18 octobre.
Lagence Reuter, a laquelle nous nous som- mes adressés, n'a pu nous fournir aucune ex- plication ; elle n’a méme pas daigné s’assurer par dépéche de l'exactitnde des chiffres.
(N.D.L.R.)

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p: Demain apres-midi dimanche, de 4 a 6 heu- res, grand concert donné par l’excellent or- chestre Hackmayer. De 6 a 7 heures, spectacle cinematographique toujours nouveau, donné par la Maison "Urbanora". Entrée PT. 5. Car nets de 25 billets P.T. 75.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN LIBERAL PARTY.
div.p: The Egyptian Liberals are very indignant at the serious charges brougbt against their leader, Mohamed Bey Wahid. Recently Kamel declared in the "Independance Belge" that Mohamed Bey Wahid had been sold to the English, who are "masters in the art of trafficking in consciences and making use of such merchandise." Nachat Bey has publicly accused Kamel of being a liar and a charlatan and declares that "Wahid Bey is far above the shameless falsehoods of a snob, who lives by begging and who from his early youth used to beg from the clients of his father who was a hairdresser."

div.head: KEIR-HARDIE AND EGYPT.
div.p: There is no confirmations of the rumour that Mustapha Pasha Kamel has been so pleased with the results of Mr. Keir Hardie's visit to India that he has invited that Member of Parliament to pay a visit to Egypt. Mr. Keir Hardie when leaving England did not include this country in his trip and is proceeding to South Africa and Australia after leaving India. The only advanced Radical M.P., who has as yet made up his mind to pay a Visit: to Egypt shortly is Dr. Rutherford, the member for Brentford. This gentleman, who is a friend of Mr. Robertson, M. P., is not likely to favour Kamel, batinhis Egyptian politics is more inclined to the views ot the Moderate Nation- alist Party.

div.head: A MODERATE'S DENUNCIATION.
div.p: “Al Moayad” devotes a leading article to the denunciation of the recklessness and irresponsibility of certain advanced Nationalist writers, and exhorts its readera to follow the advice of those who counsel a peaceful and gradual reform. “Egyptians,” says the writer, “heed not those who by their doubtfal policy give reason to the British to remain obdurate.” ‘Addressing himself to the British the writer continues, “It behoves not your high-standing and the honour of your mighty kingdom to maintain a policy of obstinacy in regard to Egypt, for such can but lead to the harm of both the governor and the governed."

div.head: THE DECLINE OF KAMEL.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes:-

The approaching visit of Mostaphe Pasha Kamel to Alexandria has aroused great interest in native circles in Cairo. The Pasha has been losing so mach ground lately that he intends to make desperate efforts to again become the undisputed leader of a united Nationalist Party. But his autocratic methods and amazing egoiam have alienated a large nnmber of his former supporters and many consider that his attacks on the English and Buropeans in general are far too venomous, The Moderate Nationalist Party, represented by “Al Moayad”, of Sheikh Aly Youssef, and “Al Minbar”, of Hafiz Effendi Awad, have of late gained greatly in the popular favour and Kamel is now looked upon only as merely the chief of one out of many hostile groups, who detest one arother more than they dislike the Occupation. The appear- ance of the new “Party of the People” was also a bitter surprise for Kamel and he had no idea how much ground he had lost in Egypt during his long stay in Enrope until he returned a few days ago. He thought that he was coming back to Egypt as the recog- nised and sathoritative apostle of Nation- alism, but on his arrival in Cairo he experienced a rude awakening. The rapture with Mr. Robertson, M.P., and the recent unfortunate proceedings which led to the departure of Mr. Rudy, the Editor of the “Egyptian Standard,” from the staff of Kamel’s English newspaper, have also had a considerable effect on pablic opinion. The Pasha’s influence in Alexandria is. said to have greatly decreased of late and his: newspaper, “Al Lewa,” no longer holds the place it did. Another bitter mortification for Kamel was the contemptuous silence with which his manifesto to Mr. Campbell-Banner- man was received in England. After the manifestoes of Hafiz Effendi Awad, in the name of the Moderate Nationalists, and of Mohamed Wahid Bey, in the name of the Egyptian Liberal Party, had reached Sir Edward Grey, they created some stir in the | London press, while Kamel’s effusion to the Premier passed absolutely unnoticed. This has been a great blow to his pride. The Pasha was also very vexed at the advent of the Egyptian Liberal Party, as the birth of this organisation was quite unexpected and he was especially annoyed to find how much notice has been taken of Mohamed Bey Wahid's policy in the English newspapers, All these marty blows at his inflaence have been so sudden and unexpected that he has been rather taken aback. He is now going to make a big effort to recover the lost ground, and for this reason be has determined to make a great ~harangue at Alexandria in order to induce the leading natives to rally round him and leave his rivals in the lurch. The general opinion, however, in Cairo is that he will never succeed in recovering his old position and that he must rest content with remaining the mere leader of one ont of many groups.

div.p: DEPARTURES.
Passengers partis hier par "l'Equateur" pour Marseilles

M. et Mme de Vesuie, M. Muhamed Ali, M. Aghum, M. Georges Mezback, M.G. Banour, Mme Maggiar et sa fille, M. Whaby, M.J. Spink et son fila, M.J. Comelly, M. George Soussa, M. A.S. Hanthopolo, M. Dupernet, M. Henidorf, M. Nicolas, M. Mitrelais et son neveu, M. Nader, M. Grandmoulin, M. Medawar, Sheikh Mahmed Mistafa Elattar, M. div.head: SHIP'S CREW NUTINIES.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent).
Port Said, Friday.

The S.S. "Coulsdon," Captain G. Turnbull, arrived here this afternoon, bound from Barry to Aden with a cargo of coal. As the vessel rounded the break-water she was seen to hoist a signal for the police to come on board at once. Immediately on arrival, the agent, accompanied by a force of port police, boarded her and found the crew in a state of mutiny, but little or no difficulty was experienced in getting the men ashore. In order to make sure of their men, however, the police sent an equal number of men to take the seamen to H. B. M.'s Consulate.

The crew, which is a native one, have several times given trouble, the first occasion being four days after leaving Barry, when the captain found it necessary to threaten two of the ring-leaders with irons the natives armed themselves and threatened "to do for" Captain Turnbull and Chief Officer Williams unless they withdrew. Similar acts occured twice during the voyage, and when in sight of land this morning the chief engineer was threatened with a shovel. Late this afternoon the men were taken before Mr. D. A Cameron, H. B. M.'s Consul-General, who sentenced six of them to one month's imprisonment each, not more than two to be in any prison at the same time.

div.head: Another Plague Case.
div.p: Another case of bubonic plague was notified here this afternoon.

div.head: The Casino Theatre.
div.p: The orchestra which has had such a successful season at the Casino and which was so very popular has been engaged by the Eastern Exchange Hotel for the passenger season. The band, which is an exceedingly good one, will no doubt attract many people to the hotel grounds.

div.head: The Khedivial Theatre.
div.p: The attractions at the Khedivial Theatre this week are rather better than the usual at Port Said. The evening's programme includes Miss Arianne, who has a most powerful voice; Miss Beatrice Milton, who makes her debut this evening; Miss Rollande, a French singer; and the Sisters Ida and Amedea Bight, who are great favourites. The latters' songs have plenty of swing in them, with good choruses which are heartily taken up by the audience. The "Two Sporting Girls," of Naples and Alexandria fame, are the chief attraction of the evening. They have a good selection of songs and dances and change their programme almost nightly. At dancing Miss Tina Caswell is by far the best Port Said has seen for many a year, while Miss Willis is a pretty dancer and is gifted with a charming voice. An artist is rarely found who can dance and sing so well.

div.head: RAYAK ALEPPO RAILWAY.
(From Our Own Correspondent.)
div.p: The Ottoman Commission delegated by the Ministry of Public Works for the definitive reception of the Rayak-Aleppo Railway arrived from Constantinople by the Messageries steamer, accompanied by Mr. Chenut, Inspector General of the Regie Generale des Chemins de Fer. After stopping at the Grand Hotel d'Orient of Messrs. Bassoul they proceeded on the next day by a special train to take final delivery of the line. The members of this commission are: Margoissian Effendi, President, Saleh Effendi, Mustapha Effendi, Farid Bey and Colonel Zia Bey. The importance of this mission is realized when it is recalled that over twenty military stations, "croisements militaires," exist on the line of siding and regular platforms, and locomotives under pressure are kept in readiness at some of these stations for instant employment in cases of emergency.

div.head: Return of Governor-General.
div.p: On the 4th instant arrived by the 11 a.m. train Khalil Pasha, Governor-General of Beyrout, after ten days' rest in the hills. A detachment of soldiers preceded by the military band was called out to most and salute him at the station. It is presumed that the return of his Excellency has been determined or hastened by the unpleasant incident of the Russian steamer.

div.head: MILITARY NOTES.
div.p: Majors F. A. B. Fryer and N. W. Haig, Captain G. W. F. Tarleton, and Lieutenant E. C. Bowen, all of the Inniskilling Dragoons, have returned from leave.
Lieutenant H. C. M. Porter, King's Royal Rifle Corps, has been granted sick leave until the 20th prox.
The headquarters of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers were transferred from Cairo to Alexandria to-day.

div.head: Cheap Gas from Common Fuels
div.p: for Engines, Manufacturing, Furnaces, Pumping, Irrigation, Incandescent Lighting and Generation of Electricity, Lane's Producers are available for Land, River or Ocean Service Agents required. Address Howard Lane, 135 Edmund Street, Birmingham, England.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Khedive has conferred the rank of Ferik on Sir Rudolphh von Slatis Pasha.
We regret to announce that the latest news from London as to Sir Auckland Colvin's condition is that he is in a very grave state.

The King has been pleased to give and grant unto Edward Andrew Roberts Creagh, Esq., his Majesty's Royal license and authority that he may accept and wear the Insignis of the Fourth Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidieh, conferred upon him by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by the Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered by him.
The Rev. Peter Rudolph, Director of the Rudolph Homes at Alexandria and Cairo, who has been very seriously ill with an internal malady and whose case was given up as hopeless, is now convalescent.

Mr. E.S. Edie, M.A., B.S.C., oil chemist to the Institute of Commercial Research in the Tropics, has been offered, and has been granted leave to accept an appointment under the Sudan Government to carry on researhc in resins during the next twelve months. Mr. Edie's work on oil investigations has attracted much atention during the last two years, and his selection to carry on important work for the Sudan Government is a great compliment to the Institute of Commercial Research.

Major Tankerville J. Chamberlayne, has retired from the public service, in which he latterly occupied the position of Commissioner and Local Commandant of Kyrenia Cyprus. He has seen a large amount of military service in various parts of the world, and was formerly Aide-de-Camp to the Governor of Natal and Private Secretary to the High COmmissioner of Cyprus.

The late British representatives in the Caisse de la Dette at Cairo, Sir Cecil Spring-Rice, who is going home from his post at Telieran, on leave, which, if not actually sick-leave, is not unconnected with the state of his health, has only been about a year in charge of our interests in those parts, though his actual appointment dates from 1895, when he was Councillor of Embassy at Petersburg. But his twelve months of residence has been no unevenful period. He has seen the election of the first Parliament that has ever sat in Persia; and, since he has been British Minister, the death of the Shah has occurred, and the Anglo-Russia Agreement has become an accomplished fact, and one of which, it is understood, Sir Cecil is not without reason to congratulate himself.

Alexandria will never again be able to welcome Sir Compton Domville in command of the Mediterranean Fleet as he retired from active service on Thursday week, on which day he celebrated his sixty-fifth birthday, the gallant sailor having been born on Oct. 10, 1842. Upwards of fifty-one years ago he became a midshipman, and in 1862 was appointed to the Royal yacht. For his "skill and gallantry" in the suppression of piracy in the China Seas, when lieutenant commanding the Algerine, he was promoted commander, and in 1888 appointed A.D.C. to the Sovereign. Sir Compton has held many oof the most important administrative offices under the Admiralty, was for some time second in command in the Mediterranean, and from 1902 until last year was chief in the great inland sea.

div.head: THE ASSOUAN BARRAGE.
PHILAE'S LEASE OF LIFE.
div.p: M. Maspero, Director of the Service of Antiquities in Egypt, stated yesterday week at the Academie des IInscriptions et Belles Lettres, Paris, that the establishing of the barrage for the irrigation of the Nile had done irreparable damage to ancient monuments which had been submerged, especially to the famous temple of Philae, which was flooded by the waters from mid-December till April.
The new irrigation scheme, in his opinion, will do even greater damage yet, for the Temple of Philae will be entirely submerged under twenty-five feet of water.

The Egyptian Government has in him the work of consolidating the temple and of carefully copying the inscriptions, but, says M. Maspero, "The Temple must be considered lost for ever, seeing that the foundations are saturated like a sponge and the land is undermined. In thirty years, at the most, the Temple will have disappeared."

EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.
RIDING BREECHES.
F. Phillips & Co.

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
FINAL ACT VOTED.
div.p: The Conference has voted the final act which was signed to-day. It includes 13 conventions, 3 declarations, and 5 resolutions.
The Hague October 18.
The Conference is over, M. de Neliduff congratulated the delegates on their work and telegraphed expressions of their gratitude to the Tsar and Mr. Roosevelt.

div.head: THE RAILWAY CRISIS.
REMOTE CHANCES OF CONCILIATION.
div.p: The railway situation is rapidly developing and the chances of concilation are becoming more remote. Some Companies have noified inspectors belonging to the Union that unless they withdraw they will be removed temporarily to lower posts to prevent their using their positions to influence the men.
Mr. Bell, speaking at St. Pancras, said that he would welcome Mr. Lloyd George or anyone intervening to prevent a strike.

div.head: THE MOROCCAN SITUATION
SULTAN SEEKS LOAN.
div.p: The French are preparing to meet an attack from Mulay Hafid's approaching force whose intentions are unknown. They are also suspicious of another force, under Marabout of Tadelat who has visited the French camp with a large escort, professing friendship.
General Drude reports that the Sultan's army is advancing on the Chaouia district, in the vicinity of Casa Blanca, where probably an encounter with Mulay Hafid's force will take place.
Paris October 18.
The newspapers say that the Council of Ministers wil accord facilities to Abd el Aziz to contract a loan.
It is hoped that Casablanca to be able to communicate with Paris next week by radio-telegraphy.

div.head: THE ITALIAN STRIKE.
DECISION OF RAILWAYS/
div.p: The State Railway Administration have decided to dismiss or degrade the strikers and grant bonuses to non-strikers.
Rome, October 18.
Three thousand railway employes have been punished for takign part in the strike.

div.head: EMPEROR JOSEPH.
A DISTURBED NIGHT.
div.p: The Emperor passed a bad night. He had severe attacks of coughing which caused considerable pain. His condition this morning is consequently less satisfactory but his appetite is good. He worked the whole forenoon.
Vienna, October 18.
The Emperor passed a disturbed night, but in the afternoon he walked up and down the gallery. Dr. Chiasi notifies a diminution in the catarrh.

div.head: MACEDONIAN REFORM.
MEETING OF AMBASSADORS.
div.p: The Ambassadors meet to-day to discuss the question of reforms in Macedonia.
It is understood that the Porte has renewed her instructions to her representatives abroad to endeavour to obtain abandonment of the project of international control.

div.head: TERRIBLE WEATHER AT HOME.
FLOODS ISOLATE VILLAGES.
div.p: Storms and rains continue. Many parts of the midlands and north of England and of Scotland have been submerged, isolating villages. The farmers are suffering severely. Wrecks and loss of life at sea are reported.

div.head: FLOODS IN ITALY.
LAKE MAGGIORE OVERFLOWS.
div.p: The floods in the northern part of the country are becoming worse. The beautiful autumn resorts of Lago Maggiore are inundated in place to the extent of 12 feet. The people have take refuge on the roofs. Enormous damage has been done.

div.head: SIR E. MALET AND MR. BLUNT.
div.p: With regard to the controversy between Mr. Wilfrid Blunt and Sir E. Malet which has been proceeding in the "Times" concerning Sir E. Malet do-day answering Mr. Blunt's suggestion that Lord Dufferin disapproved of his conduct publishes a letter from his Lordship dated 14th January 1883highly commending it. The "Times" commenting on the affair says that Mr. Blunt belongs to that misguided class who find their principal satisfaction in traducing their own countrymen.

div.head: THE ITALIAN BUDGET.
div.p: The budget for 1907 shows a surplus of at least 75,000,000 francs.

div.head: ANTI-MILITARISM IN FRANCE.
div.p: 21 persons have been committed for trial at Lyons for signing anti-militarist placards.

div.head: HOME RACING.
div.p: Middle Park Plate. 1. Lesbia; 2. Morena; 3. Araminta.
Betting. 3 to 1 Lesbia; 9 to 1 Morena; 5 to 1 Araminta. Seven ran. Won by 2 lengths. A head between second and third.

div.head: M. LAMBERT'S LETTER.
div.p: The publication here of M. Lambert's letter on his resignation of the post of Director of the Khedivial School of Law says the Cairo correspondent of the "Times," has produced an unpleasant impression; for, though M. Lambert by his own confession appears in the sorry role of sacrificing his conscience to the necessities of the situation and adduces no evidence in support of his statements, his charges are sufficiently grave to cause considerable uneasiness in the public mind, and much concern is felt for the future of the Law School, the only genuine high school in Egypt. It is hoped that Mr. Dunlop will be able to disprove the more serious accusations. In the meantime it is important to note that no question or national rivalry is involved; the real ground of the conflict is the familiar question of the independence of the competent experts in the higher faculties.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
(From our Financial Correspondent).
div.p: The following Gentlemen Cadets from Sand- hurst have been appointed Sevend ‘Lieatenants in regiments having battalions in Bgypt— King’s Own Seottish ‘Borderers, Second Lieo tenant P. N. Sanderson; Reyal I i Fusiliers, Second Lieutenant R. H. Adair ; King’s Royal Rifle Corps, Second Lieutenants A. L. Bonham-Carter, J.V.E. Lees, and PG. Chatsworth-Musters ; Royal Dublin Pusiliers, Second Lieutenant T.L.M.L. Mansfield.

The Marquis of Bristol, who is our only naval peer since the death of the Earl of Clan- williem, has been appointed to the yacht “Renown” in command, The Marqu will command: the “Renown” during her “voyage to and from England with the King and Qneen of Spain aboard

About the New Year, the battleship “Ir resistible,” Captain H. Williams, will return home and pay off She will be replaced in the Mediterranean Fleet by one of the ‘“Canopns” type of battleship. ‘Phe remaining ships of the “Formidable” class will be brought: home by the end of March next.

Captain R.F.M. Sims, D.S.0., King’ Royal Rifle Corps, who has just severed his connection with the Corps, commanded a company in the 2nd Battalion, Jubbulpore, since January, 1902. He is a Staff Collage man, and earned his decoration in the fighting from Colenso to Ladysmith, in the course of which he was wounded. Captain Sims was mentioned in despatches on two occasions, received the D.S.0., Queen’s medal with five clasps and the King's medal with two clasps.

Captain G. H. Earle, 6th Inniskiiling Dra- goons, the very smart and popular adjutant of the King’s Colonials, will complete his regulation three years in that appointment next month, bat in recognition of his great success jn this very fine corps—admittedly one of the finest in the Imperial Yeomanry — he has been granted specially an extension of two years by the Army Council. By the ex- piration of his extension Captain Rarle will be pretty near the top of the captains’ list.

Major A. H. Rutherford, 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, Alexandria, will reach the age limit of his rank on the 23rd inst., and will retire on his retired pay of £300 per annum if net promoted in the interim. Major Rutherford has spent since 1881 in the regi- ment—it was then the 102nd Foot—and he has the South African War to hi. credit. He commanded the Ceylon Contingent in the operations in Orange Free State, and in the Transvaal, inelading the actions of Poplar Grove, Johannesburg, Pretoria, Diamond Hill up till August, 1900 ; ‘and he subsequently saw farther service in the operations west of Pretoria, the actions of Elands River and Frederickstad, and the campaign generally in the ‘Transvaal and Cape Colony (Queen's medal with six clasps, King’s medal with two clasps).

In view of the departure of the 1st Dragoon: Guards for India, and the arrival at home from. South Africa, of the 20d Dragoon Guards, the Army Council has notified that the Provisiona! Cavalry Depot at Ballineollig is to be composed. of officers and men of the Ist and 5th Dragoon Guards, instead of the 2nd Dragoon Guards, and 6th Dragoons as at present. Major W. H Perse, 2nd Dragoon Gnards, Captain T. G. Gibson, and Lientenant R. M. Wood, 6tb Dragoons, and the whole of. the detaits now at Ballincollig, are accordingly to proceed to Hounslow about the 6th November, and will be replaced at Ballincollig by Captain W. H. Leckett, D.8.0. and 231 other ranks of the 1st Dragoon Guards.

In an Army Order amending the instructions in the King’s Regulations regarding sentences by conrts-martial, it is notified that “Detention” has been introduced into the scale of military punishments in order that soldiers convicted of purely military offences should not, as a tule, be subject to the stigma attached to im prisonment. The latter punishment onght generally to be reserved for men convicted of purely military offences, or of grave military offences, which, in the opinion of the court- martial, render their discharge with ignominy advisable. Where, therefore, a soldier has for a purely military offence been sentenced by a court-martial to imprisonment with discharge with ignominy, the confirming officer of other superior authority is directed, except in very special circumstances, to commute the sentence to one of detention. It is further laid down that when a sentence of imprisonment is com- mated into one of detention, the term of detention, shall in no case exceed the term of imprisonment originally awarded. A sen- tence of detention, being lower in the scale of punishments than imprisonment, cannot be commuted into one of imprisonment. Another new ruling is that when a general officer remitaa discharge with ignominy he is, at the same time, to commnate the sentence of imprisonment to one of detention.

MARRIED v. SINGLE
div.p: The "Married" were rather severely defeated by the "Bachelors" in this match yesterday. Mr. Burnham and Mr. Crake were the chief scorers for the winners. Mr. Graves' average of 5 wickets for 26 runs was a good performance. Mr. Scott Dalgleish made a fine effort for his side, making some excellent hits and was undefeated at the end. div.head: MAHOMEDAN AND CHRISTIAN.
div.p: In the “Hindustan Review” Dr. Nishikagta Chattopadhyaya contributes an interesting Ae ries of exeerpts about “Christ in the Koran.” He says :—

From the very beginning of my study of the Koran I have been greatly strack with the love and veneration with which the Prophet. of Islam always mentions the mame of Christ Jesus, so mach so that one might say in making use of a somewhat colloquial phrase that Mohamed had Christ “on the brain.” These references to Christ in the Koram carry more than usual weight chiefly for the following two reasons :—(1) Bebause they are not merely the sayings of the Prophet of Islam, but are actual revelations made throagh him by God Himself ;and (2) Because they prove beyond doubt that the Prophet of Islam was not only not the “Anti-Christ” as he has generally been supposed to be, but’ some respeots a very, very orthodox Obristian, mach more orthodox, in fact, than a good many bishops and other ecclesiastical dignitaries of modern Christen- dom.

He quotes passages to show that Mahomed called Jesus “the Word of God,” “the illnstrious Messiah,” the “intercessor” in the next world ; that he held Christ to have been conceived in the womb of the Virgin Mary by a special act ot the Divine Wit, or by the Holy Spirit ; and that He was born holy or sinless. Mahomed accepts the miracles recorded of Him. The writer declares. that Mahomed’s polemic was against carnal notions of the generation of the Son. He maintains, in conclusion, that “the logical and legitimate inference that must consequently be drawn from all the passages about Christ Jesus in the Koran is the Divinity of Christ and no other.”

div.head: SUDAN IVORY.
div.p: On account of the inconveniences experienc ed by those who wish to send such articles as ivory and ostrich feathers by mail, representa- tions have been made to the Governor of Khartoum, suggesting that arrangements might be made by the Customs and Post Office authorities to facilitate the export of such articles. At present all packages containing feather or ivory must first be brought over to Khartoum North, where taxes are colleeted and the packages sealed, and then the sender can hand them over to the Post Office for despatch. This involves a good deal of delay and trouble. The suggestion aims at avoiding all this trouble by Having the taxes paid to the Postmaster, who will act in such cases for the Customs Office. Soch an arrangement would be quite practicable, as the taxes to be collested on such articles can be easily deter. mined without the help ot experts. There are other instances where the Post Office authori- ties collect customs dues on behalf of the Castoms authorities.

div.head: CONCERNING DIABOLO
div.p: In a work on Africa, written in 1874, writes an erudite correspondent, Comte Cameron relates that he saw in Central Africa to the north of Katanga, among the people of Kassonogo’s tribe, a slave amusing his master by the cleverness with which he twirled a spool, throwing it high into the air, and catching it again on the string. He describes exactly the now fastionsble game of diabolo, known for centuries in China and in Africa, and now re- discovered in England.

div.head: ERGOPHOBIA.
div.p: Last week Arthur Ubilcot, who was described as the laziest man in Kngland, was brought up for sentence as an incorrigible, at Croydon Quarter Sessions.

There have been twenty-seven convictions agaist Chiloot since 1908 for refusing to perform his task in the workhouse, and it was stated that once at Kingston-on-Thames he made. the police carty him to the station. When in the dock to-day he went to sleep, and it was with difficulty that he was aroused.

The workhouse dootor said that Chiloot was suffering from ergophobia, and the Recorder, in sentencing him to twelve months’ imprison: ment, remarked that he could not understand, why the mana should prefer hard work in gaol to easy work outside.

div.head: La Semaine
div.p: Notre marché, tavorablement inflaencé par le Stock Exchange, a été soutenu lundi ; plu- sieurs valeurs ont bénéficié d'une nonvelle avance, qui a été pour quelques-unes fort appréciable Dans l'ensemble pourtant on s’at- tendait & mieux et la cléture, un pea plus faible que le début, a été ane désillusion pour un certain nombre. Inutile d'ajoater que les transactions sont restées clairsemées et limitées comme importance A une petite catégorie de valeurs, dont V Agricole, la Cassa di Sconto, l’Union Fonciére et la Béhéra.

Que cela pfovint des cours de Paris arrivés en baisse oa de la tendance générale a réaliset de la part dé nos spéculatears a courte éché- ance, toujours est-il- que la tenue a été man- vaise be lendemain. L’ élément vendeur a dominé pendant toute I séance, sans d'aillears rénssit a se défaire dé quantités appréciables. Led échanges, dissétpinés un peu sur toute [a cote, n'ont eu aucyn® importance, méme sur led titres les pigs en vogue, Baehler, Comptoir, Agricole et Cette dernitre a cependant fait l'objet dane demande trés active.

Mercredi, on a été encore plus déprimé. Tout le monde voulait liquider a la fois et les acheteurs faisant défaut, la cote a sabi une nouvelle atteinte. Natuorellement les tran actions, minimes et clairsemées, ont été effec- tuées 4 des prix inférieurs et disséminées tin pen sur toutes les valeurs offertes, en parti- calier la National Bank, l’Agricole, le Comptoir, l'United, l'Urbaine, les Nungovich et la! Building Lands.

La tendance a liquider s'est transformée hier et aujourd'hui en véritable détoge d'ordres de vente. [1 en tombait de partoot. Le Caire surtout cherchait 4 se débarraaser de liasses de Cassa di Sconto et de Delta Land. En l'absence caractérisée d'acheteurs, l'empresse- ment des vendeurs n'a pu étre satisfait que moyennant une nonvelle réduction de leurs exigences. Encore les échanges sont ils restés rares et de peu d'envergure.

div.head: Les Flunctuations de la Cote
div.p: Dans de telles conditions on ne sera pas sur- pris de constater que sur une soimantaine de valeurs inscrites A la cote officielle de la Bourse d’Alexanidrie, 36 soient en baisse et 3 seulement en hansse, les autres demeurant stationnaires aux cours antérieurs, c'est X-dire, compléte- ment négligées.

Grace a une demande qui ne s'est ralentie qu'aujourd’hai, la Béhéra a atteint 23 7/8, en gain de 1 5/8. En raison d'une offre non moins permanente, les Nungovich Hotels ont perdu 2 livres @ 16 3/4, la Nile Land 4 litres a 9, la fondatear United 5/8 a 7/8, et le Comp- toir 5/16 V'action a 27/8 l'ancienne et 215/16 la nouvelle et 7/16 la part de fondateur a 2 1/16.

Vis-a-vis de ces chutes sensationnelles et non moins rapides qne leur hausse de naguére, les changements suivants paraltront peo signi- ficatifs ; 1/4 de recul sur la Daira a 13 5/8, 7 franes sur l’Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier 4 296, 4 francs sir les Lots Tares a 161, 6 francs sur la Cassa di Sconto a 48, 7/32 sur la Delta Land a 1 1/2, 9 32 sur la Building Lands 4 2 1/82, 8/16 sur I’Union Fonciére et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien aux cours respectifs de 43/4 et 4.1/8, 1/4 sur l’action Allotment 4 21/8 et 5/8 sur la fondateur Zariffa a 35.5. A remarqner quece dernier résultat a été ob tenu par la simple vente aux enchéres de 5 titres.

En baisse également l'Agricole de 3 32 a 8 7/32, In National Bank de 116 a 21 7/8 lea Tramways Privilégiées de 1 fr. 1/2 4 141, la Delta Light de 1/16 a 10 1/4, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire de 1 fr. a 194, les Markets de 6 pence a 27/-, la Spinning de 1/16 4 5/16, la Salt and Soda de 9 penve a 17/9, l'Obligation nouvelle Crédit Foncier de 3 fr. a 254, la Ban- que d’Athénes de 1 fr.A 110, la Differed Delta de 1/8 a 7 1/2, l'Investment de 1/32 a 13/32, la Land Bank de 3:16 A 7 1/4, les Estates de 3/32 a 9/16, I'Urbaine de 116 a 3 3/4, l'Aboukiry de 3 pence a 28/6, la Levant de 1/164 1/2, Vaction United de 1,32 a1 4, les Ritz de 1/16 49/16, l'Helouan de 1 32a 5/32 et la Levico de 1/16 a 7/16.

Les autres titres en avance sont, a part ‘a Béhéra déja mentionnée, la Khedivial Mai! de 4 a 4 1/8 la Privilégiée et de 21/ a 22/31 l'Or dinary. Cette derniére principalement a été demandée pendant toute la semaine.

div.head: Ventes aux Encheres Publiques
div.p: Au cours de la huitaine, il a été venduanx enchéres publiques 100 actions anciennes Upper Egypt Hotels a 2 7/8 et 40 nouvelles a 21/2, 200 Lunghis a 21/64, 200 a 1 4 et 250 a 15/64, 500 actions United a 17/64 et 1504 1/4, 100 Delta Land 4 1 43/64, 50 actions anciennes Comptoir Financier a 3 19/64, 25 Building Lands a 25/16, 25 Crédit Franco- Egyptien a 4 11/32, 200 Hooker (Land and General Trust) A 25/64 et 2004 13/82, 5 fon- dateurs Sednaoui Zarifta A 313 32, 100 Uasis (Corporation of Western Egypt) a 31/64, 100 Agricole a 8 15/64 et 150 Karam (Industrial and Building) a 21/64.

Bien qu’au fond ces ench res ne puissent avoir d'effet matériel sur le-marché, puisqne d'ordinaire les courtiers qui font vendre sont eux-méniés les acheteurs déguisés, cependant, elles n’en produisent pas moins On effet moral déplorable. C'est du moins ce qu'on prétend dans la corbeille.

div.head: Nos Places Dirigeantes
div.p: C'est aux places dirigeantes que nos cour tiers reprochent principalement la réaction ac- tuelle. Le fait est qu'au Stock Exchange la Daira, |'Agricole et la National Bank ont perdu 1/8 aux pfix respectifs de 13 3/4, 8 3/8 et 21 7/8; dautre part, lé Consolidé Anglais a rétro-

gradé de 83 a 82 8/4, ainsi gqne I'Unifi¢e Egyp- tienne de 103 4 102 8/4. La Bourse de Paris pe fait pas meilleure figure: le Ciédit Foncier Egyptien yareculé de 2 fr. a 698, Ia Land Bank of Egypt de 5 fr. a 185, et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 2 fr. a 109. Quant a la Rente Francaise, elle a perda seulement 2 points a 94.10.

On voit par ces quelques mots que si dans la légére réaction des bourses européennes on peut trouver l'explication du fiéchissement proportionnel de nos valeurs dirigeantes, il faut s'adresser a la spéculation locale pour trouver le motif des moins-values sensation- nelles qui nous avons eu @ enregistrer sur quelques-uns de nos titres spéculatifs.

div.head: La Situation Generale
div.p: Evidemment la cessation des achats de titres égyptiens au Stock Exchange a produit ici du malaise, immédiatement suivi d'une transformation générale des positions acheteurs en positions vendeurs. Les spéculateuts a courte échéance, lessenls a pea prés qui tra vaillent chez nous en ce moment, craignant de voircompromis les bénéfices eoquis par la hauase continue de cea derniers temps, sont presses de réaliser. Les banqnes de repprts naguére sur la pente de la failliteet depnis quelques semaines au guet, veulent aussi se débarrasser an moins au partie de comptes par trop génants et cherchent 4 liquider a la faveur de la reprise. Malheureusement ces gens qui assistaient A la hausse avec une anxiété fébrile de s'alleger au premier moment opporton et en tous cas avant la réaction, ont été surpris tons a la fois par la retraite subite des ache- teurs londoniens, contraints 4 l'attitude ex pectante par la manvaise allure des bourses américaines. New York n'a jamais été anssi manvais ; le resserrement monétaire qui sévit la-bas oblige les établissements, de crédit a une réserve qui fait jeter a Wall Street des paquets de valeurs industrielles. Il est éerit, parait il, que l'Amérique noira toujours a la apéculation égyptienne: aprés le coton, les valeurs. Si encore on avait l'espoir de rétablir ici le marché 4 terme, peut étre pourraiton aller de l’avant ; mais cet espoir méme doit tre abandonné faute de surface dela part de nos agents de change.

En ce qui concerne le tanx privé d'escompte, il a haussé de 44 3/8 %. A mesare qu'il s‘approche du taux officiel il est craindre que la Banque d'Angleterre ne soit bientdt obligée d'augmenter le sien, La proportion de se*ré- serve a été encore réduite durant cette semaine a cause de l'exportation d'or + destination de l'Egypte et d'antres pays; elle se compare toutefois avantageusement avec le chiffre de de l'année passée qui était Ala méme date de de 37 3/4 %.

div.head: Un peu de statistique
div.p: Pour répondre a un désir qui nous a été ex- primé bien des fois nous allons donner un état comparé de In cote de ce jour avec celle de la date correspondante en 1906. De cette facon on verra d'un seul coup-d'wil le graphique décrit par notre portefeuille depuis uneannée, Avant de commencer, nous ferons observer qu'il s’agit de chiffres approximatifs ; les titres ont été groupés par proportion de perte, afin de ne pas fatiguer le lecteur par une kyrielle interminable de chiffres. Naturellement la compsraison n'a pu étre etablie qn'avee les titres coteés en octobre 1906 et qui sont au nombre de 44. Les prix mentionnés indiquent le montant gagné on per lu.
4 valeurs ont béneficié d'une avance : les Markets ont gagn¢, en effet, 3 pence, les Lots Tarcs 14 francs, les Sacreries 15 france et bes Splendid Hotels 7/16, soit prés dune demi- livre.
4 valeurs ont perdu de 1 a 10 %. : Ce sont l'obligation nouvelle Crédit Foncier 20 fr., les Nungovich Hotels 1 livre 5/8, la Privilégiee Khédivial Mail 5/16 et le Banco di Roma 8 fr.

10 sont en perte de 10a 20 %. Ce sont : la National Bank 5 livres, l’Agricole ! 9/16, la Delta Light 1 3/4, les Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie 44 fr., Alexandria Water 2 livres 1/4, la Daira 3 livres, Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier 40 fr. la Land Bank 1 livre 11/16, le Cheikh Fadl 17 fr. et la Banque d'Orient 17 fr.

5 accusent un reenl de 20 a 30 7%. Ce sont : les Privilégides Tramways 46 fr. la Salt and Soda 6 shellings, la Banque d’Athénes 34 fr., l'Union Foneiére 1 livre 1.2, et le Crédit Franco Kgyptien 1 livre 3°16.

7 subissent une moins-valne de 30 a 40 %. Duns cette catégorie figurent la Rainleh 2 livres 1/2, la Beéhéra 15 livres, la Privilégi¢e Bidre d'Alexondrie 73 fr. et la Dividende 40 fr., la Priviléyive Biére du Caire 44 fr, la Differed Delta 5 livres 1/4, et l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail 14 shellings.
Les 3 suivantes rétrogradent de 40 a 50% 5 la Dividende Biére da Caire 41 fr., la Nile Land 7 livres 7/16, et I'Urbaine 2 5/8.

Dans la derniére catégorie nous avons com- pris tous les titres ayant perdu de 50% a 75 et 80 %. Ils sontan nombre de 11: l'Anglo- Egyptian Spinning 9/16, les Cotton Mills £ shellings, la Cassa di Sconto 184 fr., l'Anglo American Nile 3 livres 1/8, la Delta Land 2 livres 5/16, Investment 7/8, les Estates 1 livre 1/2, le Comptoir 4 livres les actions ancienne et nouvelle et 3 le dixiéme de part de fondateur, et la Building Lands 3 livres.

Ces chiffres qui dénotent déja une dépré- ciation énorme dans leur ensemble serdient encore plus eloquents si nous avions pris les cours maximum de chaque valeur. Mainte- nant, faut il dire que la baisse actuelle est exagérée on que la hauase avait atteint un degré de folie? Nous laissons aux capitalistes le soin de répondre ; ila savent a quel taux on peut capitaliser avantagensement tel ou tel titre en Egypte ot il existe par ailleurs tant de placements rémunérateurs. Qnant a espérer des poussées epéculatives irraisonnées, analo- gues a celles des deux ou trois années précé- dentes, nons croyons qu'il y faut renoncer pour assez longtemps.

div.head: Coton.
div.p: Si jusqu’a la semaine dernitre nous pou- vions, A bon droit, soutenir que les hanssiers qui menaient le train depuis quelque n‘avaient aucune importance, a cause de petit nombre naturellement et des quan forcément limitées qu’'ils pouvaient garder, partir d'aujourd’bui i] n’en saurait étre méme : Des faiseurs ardents, hardis et opé en grand d’babitude, se sont mélés de la partie et quoique aprés tout il n’y aft annee comparaison possible a faire entre cette anne et la dernieré au point de vue du développe- ment des fajecs’ il n’en est pas moins vral que le marehé commence a montrer plus den’ vergure et que la situdtion présente mainte nant beaucoup plus d’interet.

Que les nonveaux venus réussissent ou né réussissent pas, cela est nne autre question; mais ce qai est un fait o'est que le marché sorti de la monotonie dans laquelle fl etal tombé aprés los éyénemetits financiérs de cet été, et.qve la spécnlation n'est pas morte on que, du moins, elle renait de ses cendres. Tant mienx, car en somme personne ne saurait sonhaiter antre chose que lactivité.

Quant a l’historiqae dela sémaine, il n'est pas long. La premiére journée n’a rien eu de particulier, les conrs étant restés fermes, mais sans grandes affaires. Toutefois, les ven- deurs étant rares, les dispositions des déten teurs descontratssemblaient plutat belliqueases et n’attendre qn’an encouragement pour sé faire jour.

Et de fait, avec les avis de fermeté de New: York, la journée de Lundi nous valut une avance de 9/32, mais en réalité ce heat que Mardi matin, quand les dépéches nous eurent! annones qu'ily avaitdn Killing Frost en Amé- rique que le découvert s'est ému et a com mencé a se racheter.

Il est vrai que cette nouvellé a été démentie le lendemain, mais le branle était déjd donné et comme, défant de cet appui, nous avons en la modération des recettes et l'importance dea exportations, sans compter la persistance des rapports alarmistes mais quelque pen imaginaires au sujet de la récolte, la fermeté s'est accentuee et depuis lors les prix n'ont ceasé de monter pen a la fois, mais dane facon réguliére.

Cette tenue, considérée comme encoura- geante, a fini par nous amener les gros taiseurs et la conséqnence de tout cela est que nous finissons la semaine sur la cote de 19 25/32 pour le Novembre, soit 4 7/8 de tal: lari au-dessus de Vendredi dernier. Au plns haut et en passant, on avait fait 19 15/16, mais le cours n'a pu se maintenir a cause de quelques réalisations plutét importantes. En tous cas, l'activité a été grande, surtout de- puis hier.

Ce résultat constitue une véritable surprise pour tout le monde et les plus étonnés sont pent-étre les haussiers mémes ; et a preave de cette impression, nous ne voulons que le fait que les premiers promoteurs du mouvemént se sont arrétés A mi-chemin et ont presque entiere- ment passé leur paquét aux aux autres. Dans tous les cas, cela importe pen, le point prin- cipal étant le fait acquis. Seulement, l'impres- sion générale est qde la continwation des ma- no-uvres actuelles n’a pas sa raison d’étre ou que du moins elle serait sur le point de devenir dangerease: La filature se tient toujours sur la réserve, car les ehoses semblent clocher du coté de l'industrie, et pour ce qui est dela récolte, nous pouvons afirmer que la plapart de nos grandes maisons travaillant avec I'inté- rieur sont toujours del’avis qu'elleest supérieure Alaprécédente Il ya eu certainement des dégata, mais les informations ont été enfiées A dessein par les intéressés et pour ceux qui voudraient nous contredire, nous dirons que depuis hier les haussiers admettent eux-mémes que les nouvelles de l'intérieur ne sont plus anssi mao- vaises qu'on l'avait fait croire.

Et puis, pourquoi perdre de vue si facilement la question de la consommation possible de l'Egyptien? Sans compter le surplus dans le stock en filature au 31 Aout, stock qui était de beaucoup supérieur a celui de lannée précé- dente, n’avons-nous pas la question du Sea Island qui donne pleine récolte cette année, ce qui fera que l'Amérique pourra se passer de 40,000 balles qu'elle a df prendre en plus de chez nous pour remplacer ce genre qui Ini faisait défaut ? En outre, la qualité des lon guesoie n'est-elle pas réussie cette année et cela contrairement 4 ce quel'on avait cra aun moment donné! Pour s'en convaincre on n’a qu'a faire un peu plas de cas de ce que les gros exportateurs Américains affirment depuis plu- sieurs semaines déja.

De plus et d’une facon plus générale, croit- on sériensement que les manufacturiers améri cains auraient rédoit leurs prix de vente de 15 % si l'indystrie cotonniére allait bien? Et cette baisse des principales matiéres premiéres ne dit-elle done rien?

Et finalement la mauvaise réussite des ré- coltes des céréales en Amérique, aussi bien qu'en Europe et aux Indes, n‘at-elle done aucune importance? Ce ne sera pas des pays souffrant ou menacés de la faim que la de-' mande pour les manufactures viendra, comme aussi il est tout aussi certain que la cherté do pain aura pour résultat une certdine diminu- tion de la consommation dans les antrés contrées.

Nous ne croyons pas, malgré tout cela, A des ruines, mais il nous semble que la prudence exigerait dese montrer moins chauds et qué nos hauSsiers devraient tenir compte un peu de toutes les circonstances avant dé se lancer téte baissée dans les grandes opérations, en comptant sur lenr oumipdtetios seulemént.

La tenne du disponible chez nous déroute un peu les esprits 4 tel point que les mal: ren- seignéscroient toujours a une continuation de la demande du dehors, Tel n'est pourtant pas le cas et si nos exportateurs, qui ne sont pas tous logés a la méme enseigne comme ventes faites.

div.head: HAPPY WOMEN PRAISE PERU-NA

p.hi: It Is Works, Not Words, That Has Made Peru-na Famous Throughout the Land.

div.p: The miss and the matron alike praise Peruna. Girls and women have all discovered the value of Peruna. The Miss abd Mrs. have been ill, each in her own peculiar way, and have found relief by taking Peruna.

Fair girls and beautiful women, frail daughters and ailing mother everywhere have taken Peruna and know its value in the relief of ailment peculiar to their sex. From the grandmother to the girl babe the gentler sex are under numerous obligations to Peruna.

All this being true and the woman does not hesitate to tell it, her words win the confidence of other women, and thus the fame of Peruna spreads from household to household, until missions of homes acknowledge Peruna as their favorite and reliable family medicine.

Peruna is good for many minor ills. It can be relied upon to mitigate the many disagreeable effects of colds and irregularities so common among women. All the ailment of the catarrhal nature belong within the scope of Peruna's remedial action.
Peruna cured, me in a very short time.
MRS. SOPHIA CALDWELL
Peruna has made me a well and happy girl.
MISS ANNIS HENDREN
Miss Annie Hendren, Rocklyn, Wash., writes:

"I feel better than I have for over four years. I have taken several bottles of Peruna and one bottle of Manalin. I can now do all of my work in the house, milk the cows, take care of the milk, and so forth.

"I think Peruna is the most wonderful medicine. I believe I would be in bed to-day if I had not written to you for advice. I had taken all kinds of medicine, but none did me any good. Peruna has made me a well and happy girl. I can never say too much for Peruna."

"I suffered with female troubles for thirteen years, and tried the best doctors in Louisville, Ky., without relief, I spent thousands of dollars at the Springs. The doctors desired that I have an operation performed to remove my ovaries, which I would not consent to. I saw an advertisement of your Peruna and bought one bottle, and before I had taken it all I could get out of bed and walk about. After taking three bottles I was as well and heaty as ever. I gained in flesh from one hundred and eighteen to one hundred and eighty six pound. If it had not been for your great and wonderful medicine I would now be in my grave. I would advise all women sufferers to try it. I would not be without it for the world."-Anna Munden, Hollygrove, Ark.

"I was troubled with very serious pelvic weakness, which exhausted me so that I feared I would lose my mind. I suffered agony with my back, the pain extended down my left leg. The pain was so severe that I would have welcomed death as a relief. Peruna cured me of this trouble,- no wonder I recommend it so highly. It will soon be two years since I found relief from the pain and not a sign of it has returned. I am glad that there is a way in which I can speak of this, as many a sufferer may read my testimonial, and not only read, but believe."-Mrs. Wm. Henderson, Craik, N.W.T., Can.

'I feel it my duty to write and tell you of the good Peruna has done for me. I was subject to female weakness. For six years I suffered more or less. We consulted various doctors, who gave me relief, but no cure. I have suffered a great deal, and my husband had very large bills to pay.

"In my despair I decided to try Peruna, and the first bottle taken according to your directions gave me relief. I have had no backset since then. Since we have used Peruna, a doctor has seldom been in our house." Mrs. Martha Fredrich, Central Park, L. I., N. Y.
For special directions everyone should read "the Ills of Life," a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists.

sont constamment sur le marché, c'est qu’ils ont tont simplement des engagements qu’ils tachent d’executer pour profiter des circonstan- ces favorables qui se présentent A eux Et puis, est-ce que quelques arhitragistes n'ont pas déja commencé a opérer.

La question des exportations actuelles est aussi de nature 4 tromper la spéculation : tout ce qui s'embarque pour l'Angleterre ne va pas a la filatare ponr le moment ; car pour des nécessités d'argent, en face du refus de nos banques de clouer leurs fonds (és-a-présent, les maisons de commerce, qui ont deja acheté dans l'intérieur le coton contre leurs ventes a livrer Novembre et mois suivants, embarquent la marchandise par anticipation pour la tenir én dépot la-bas et ne la livrer qu'aox echean- ces respectives. En attendant, elles peuvent obtenir en Angléterre sur ces cotons les avan: ces qu’elles ne trouvent pas ici. Ces renseigne- ments nous ont été coufirmés par des exporta- teurs mémes Du reste, d'ici deux on trois semaines, la chose paraitra dans les Stock de Liverpool et de Manchester. Ce point n'est pas a etre perdu de vue non plus, car, s'il soulage momentanément la place, il finira d'ici peu de temps par se traduire par une réduction dans nos exportations pour l’Angleterre.

Le Novembre 1908 est moins en faveur an- prés de la spéculation: on commence a trouver que si notre récolte a réellement souffert, l’effet s’en fera sentir sur les échéances tapprochées, tandis que pour ce qui est de année prochaine, e'est tout simplemeut da jeu de hassard.
L'échéance en question a fini a 19 21/32.
En Amérique, la gréve des portefaix con- tinue, ce qui affecte l'Octobre, tandis que l'on parle dan corner sur Décembre.
Price parle de 13 1/2 millions de balles et Neill Brs estiment l'acréage a 34,000,000 d'acres.
Notre marché du disponible, comme dit plus haut, a été actif et les bonnes qualit3s sort trés fermes. Les provenances Haute Egypte aussi sont plus recherch es.

Quant aux prix, la cote officielle de ce matin nons dondé 5/8 de hansse pour les Mit Affifi, 8/4 por les Haute-Fgypte, 3/8 pour le Joan- novich, 1/4 a 1/2 pourle Nubari qui eat plus en favéur, et 1/4 senlement pour l’Abassi. moins rate sur le marché depuis quelques jours.
Les exportations dle la semaine ont fini par atteindre le total de 27000 balles environ, contre 23000 l'année derniére.
Liverpool a manque dentrain pour le dis, ponible egyptien.
Comme prix, on signale toutefois une hausse de 1/8 a la cote de 10 2/16.
Pour ce qui est des future, le Novembre fiuit a 10 6/64, soit 26/64 de hausse.
Les Americains ont ete actifs et comme prix ils cloturent a 6.53 pour le spot, 6.14 pour l'Octobre-Novembre et 5.96 pour le Janvier-
Fevrier, soit respectivement 2.9 et 3 points de hausse sur Vendredi passe.

Hull est ferme, mais n'a pas dépassé £ 7. 2/6 pour l'Octobre.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: Consulat Imperial d'Allemagne a Alexandrie.
div.p: Le Mercredi 23 Octobre 1907 a 10 heurss du matin il sera procede a la vente aux encheres publiques par l'huissier du Tribunal Consulaire d'Allemagne de 60 douzaines der de rabot.
Cette vente sera faite en vertu d'un titre executoire du Tribunal Consulaire Allemand et aura lien au Consulat d'Allemagne en ville.
Paiement comptant en or. Reception immediate, 5% droit de criee.
Alexandrie, le 18 Octobre 1907.
L'Huissier du Tribunal COnsulaire Allemand

div.head: Aufgebot.
div.p: Es wird hiermit bakannt gemacht, dass fer wurtembergische Staatsangehorige Karl Gustav Adolf Hess, seines Standes Haufmann, gch ren in Stuttgart, 33 Jahre alt, wohnhaft in Alexandrien. Sohn des im ALter von 41 Janren in Stuttgart verstorbenen Kaufmanns Albert Hess, und dessen im Alter von 37 Jahren in Nurnberg verstorbenen Ehefran Karoline geborene Reiner
und

die franzosische Staatsangehorige Eugenie Rose Pauline Pech, geboren in Samsoun, 18 Janre alt, wohnhaft in Pera, Tochter des 54 Jahre alten Issimer Pech, Angeitellier der russischen Handels & Schiffahrtagenellse haft in Pera, und seiner im Alter von 90 Jehren in Samsoun verstorbenen Ehefrau Pauline geborene Gantoni, beabaichtigen sich mit eimander zu verehelichen und diese Ehe in Gemassheit des Reichagesetaes vom 4 Mai 1870 vor dem nnterzeichneten Beamten absuschliessen.
Alexandrien, den 17 Oktober 1907.
In Vertresung
31125-1gez. v. Gaunau.

div.p:

SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
“Investments” (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning “Egyptian Gazette.”

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES BY CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres est renseigne en hausse de 1/8 a 4 3/8 pour cent.

Au Stock-Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a hanseé de 1/8 A 82 8/8. L'Unifiée a baissé de 1/4 2102 3/4. La National Bank a été ra- menée 4 21 7/8 en réaction de 1/4. La Daira a fiéchi de 1/8 a 18 3/4 et l’Agricole de 1/8 a 8 3/8. La Delta Light s'est maintenue a 10 1/2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a été soutenu a 698, la Banque d’Athénes a 111 et les Lots Turcs a 168.
Ici, la baisse de nos valeurs A Londres et la continaation dela hansse du taux de l'es- compte ‘ont encore inflaencé notre marché dont la tenue était déja si peu favorable.
La réaction n’a épargné aucune section de la cote, s'appesantissant surtout sur les petites valeurs, mais platdt nominalement, car les af- faires ont été trés limitées.

On voit la canse de cette persistance de Ja baisse dans les liquidations forcées ou volon- taires qui continuent avee une régularité dé sespérante. Il faudrait cependant s’attendre, dit-on, a on arrét . trés prochain des exécutions vo que les tribunaax ont déeidé de ne plus au- toriser de ventes anx enchéres ou des liquida- tions de dossiers.

Dans le compartiment des siete la Na- tional Bank tombe a 21 3/4 par sympathie avec Londres. La Cassa di Sconto s’affaisse A 49. Le Comptoir Financier et Commercial revient 4 27/8 et Ia Société Générale arp tienne 4 210.

La Daira Sanieh recale a 13 5/8. Le Crédit Fonecier Egyptien se présente a 693 sans affai- res, son Obligation ancienne baisse A 295-296 et la nouvelle 4 251-252. La Béhéra est ramenée a 28 5/8, L’ Allotment faiblit 4 2 1/16 et la fon- dateur a P.T 58. La fondateur Enterprise and Development réteograde a 11 3/4. Les Entre- prises Immobiliéres et Travaux sont fermes a 2 bien que les parts s'inscrivent en tasse- ment a P.T. 38-39, L’Union Fonciére est faible a 4 8/4-18/16.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovich se consolident A 163/4. Les Baehler sont moins soutenns a 6 1/16-1/8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la New Egyptian mollit 4 13/-. Les Estates retombent a 0 9/16 et les Abdy A 0 3/8. Les Egyptian Construc tions sont en meilleures dispositions a 0 5/16- 3/8 ainsi que l’Ordinary Khedivial Mail qui hausse A 22/9-28/-. La Salt and Soda s’a lourdit 4 18/-, et les Oasis (Western Egypt) a 0 7/16-1/2.
Au sujet de la réaction qui s'est de nouveau abattue sur les marchés américains et s'est répereutée comme d’habitude surceux d’Ru- rope nous lisons dans a’ “Information” de Paris :

“Les cours dot plupart des valears inter- nationales sont ahe fois de plus en déroute. Ce nouveau pas vers des niveanx de plus en plus bas est encore df, est il besoin de le dire, a la situation du marché de New-York, qui, loin de s’éelaircir, devient chaque jour plus obscare, et aussi a la baisse ininterrompue du cuivre a laquelle s'est joint aujourd’hui un reoul par- ticuliérement sensible des autres métaux, no- tamment du plomb et de l’étain.

“La dépréciation des cotes du marché am4 ricain est si importante a l'heure actuelle, que nombre de bons esprits commencent 4 penser que nous touchons 4 peu prés aux plus bas cours que l'on puisse coter sur ces comparti ments.

“Si l'on prend, en effet, les prix pratiqués aux époques des plus dures dépressions par les grands Chemins américains et cangdiens, par les valeurs de trusts et Jes valeurs territoria- les, on s'apergoit qu'il n'y a presque plus de marge de baisse A l’heure actuelle. D’autre part, en caloulant le taux de capitalisation de ces titres, d’aprés les derniers dividendes distri- baés, on se rend compte que ce taux de capita- lisation est actaellement des plus copieux, et qu’a moins de prétendre que les bonnes valeurs indastrielles américaines. doivent dorénavant se capitaliser a 10 %, il faut bien admettre que l’ére de réaction devrait logiquement, dans ur. délai assez court, prendre fin.
“On Voit donc que la baisse n'est pas parti- culiére a l’Egypte et que comme en Rarope un optimisme sensé serait de mise.”
Csrnet de l'actionnaire.

div.head: The Egyptian Salt and Soda Company, Ltd.
div.p: The Shareholders of the Egyptian Salt & Soda Company Limited are informed that, by decision of the Board an interin dividend of 39 milleiemes per share being 4 per cent, will be payable on and after November 1st 1907 at the Offices of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo, Alexandria and London on presentation of Coupon No 7.

Messieurs les Actionnaires de l'Egyptian Salt & Soda Company Limited sont informes que par decision du Conseil d'Administration un dividende interimaire de 39 milliemes par action soit 4% leur sera paye a partir du ler Novembre 1907 aux Caisses de la National Bank of Egypt au caire, a Alexandrie et a Londres, contre remise du coupon No 7.
Alexandrie, le 16 Octobre 1907. 31116-3-3

1. - Demoiselle tres instruite donnerait a domicile des lecons de francais, d'allemand et de piano.
2. - Dame honorable louerait chambre confortablement meublee, rue Saleh el Din.
3. - Jeune dame tres honorablement connue, connaissant italien, francais et arabe, donnerait des lecons de broderie et de piano, ou accepterait place comme dame de compagnie.
4. - Comptable experimente pour les agences de Bourse cherche place. Bonnes referencees.
5. - Comptable correspondant accepterait place aux villages ou au Caire.
6. - Ancien employe de magasins de confection cherche place. Tres bonnes references.
7. - Aiden comptable d'agence de Bourse cherche place.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
